headline.main: Cleaning Up After the Enron Verdicts

docs.snippet: Houston residents prefer to focus on things other than the Enron trial, like the resurgent economy....
docs.lead_paragraph: A big trial starts in federal court here on Monday, involving some very prominent executives who used to work for a very prominent company. Across the country, people will be following the case with great interest. But in Houston, many residents prefer to focus on other things, like the resurgent economy, and city leaders wish outsiders would, too. The company, of course, is Enron, and the men who will be on trial are its former top executives, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, who face various charges in the scandal that led to the company's collapse and tarred this city's reputation four years ago.

headline.main: There's No E in Houston; As an Enron Trial Approaches, Residents Prefer to Focus on the Present

docs.snippet: A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about the plans of Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, to work as a volunteer for Habitat for Humanity misidentified the source of his M.B.A. degree. It was Harvard, not the Kell...
docs.lead_paragraph: A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about the plans of Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, to work as a volunteer for Habitat for Humanity misidentified the source of his M.B.A. degree. It was Harvard, not the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern.
docs.abstract: Correction of Aug 29 article: Jeffrey K Skilling got his MBA from Harvardm

docs.snippet: In his song ''They Want It All,'' David Crosby laments about corporate greed without mentioning anyone by name. But that the song, which he has been singing for more than a year, doesn't lack a target. ''It's about Enron, no question,'' he told Th...
docs.lead_paragraph: In his song ''They Want It All,'' David Crosby laments about corporate greed without mentioning anyone by name. But that the song, which he has been singing for more than a year, doesn't lack a target. ''It's about Enron, no question,'' he told The Associated Press last week. ''When I introduce it, I say it's about Enron.'' Mr. Crosby -- who knows something about the justice system, having spent time in a Texas prison in 1985 after being convicted on drug and gun possession charges (overturned on appeal) -- said he was irritated over how long it took to indict Enron's chairman, Kenneth L. Lay.
docs.abstract: David Crosby says his song about corporate greed is about Enron; is annoyed by how long it took to indict Enron chairman Kenneth L Lay; photo (S)

docs.snippet: A federal judge ordered Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, to stop drinking and put him on a curfew in response to a drunken scuffle outside a New York City bar last month.       Prosecutors wanted Magistrate Frances Stacy t...
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ordered Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, to stop drinking and put him on a curfew in response to a drunken scuffle outside a New York City bar last month. Prosecutors wanted Magistrate Frances Stacy to increase Mr. Skilling's bond to $7 million from $5 million, prohibit travel outside of Texas and impose a midnight curfew.

headline.main: Curfew Imposed on Former Enron Chief

docs.snippet: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, has tentatively agreed to plead guilty to fraud charges and has provided evidence against another former high-ranking executive who is expected to face criminal charges as soon as this...
docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, has tentatively agreed to plead guilty to fraud charges and has provided evidence against another former high-ranking executive who is expected to face criminal charges as soon as this week, people involved in the case said yesterday. A plea by Mr. Fastow and, if it happens, the charging and arraignment of Richard A. Causey, the former chief accounting officer, would be the most significant turning point in the two-year criminal investigation into the collapse of Enron, the energy-trading company.
docs.abstract: Former Enron chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow reportedly tentatively agrees to plead guilty to fraud charges and has provided evidence against another former top executive; deal, which involves prison sentence of at least 10 years, reportedly hinges in part on resolution of related case against Fastow's wife, Lea; federal judge rejects her deal because it leaves him no ability to increase five month prison sentence, possibly delaying husband's plea and expected charges against Richard A Causey, former chief accounting officer; deal with Fastow and pressure on Causey means prosecutors have reached high enough in Enron to determine whether knowledge of wrongdoing reached former chief executives Jeffrey K Skilling and Kenneth L Lay; table of people swept up in probe; photos (M)

headline.main: EX-ENRON FIGURE REPORTEDLY NEAR A PLEA OF GUILTY

docs.snippet: Enron, which owed more than $67 billion after collapsing into bankruptcy protection, can seek creditors' support for a recovery plan that gives them most of the energy company's assets, a federal judge ruled yesterday. The judge, Arthur Gonzalez, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enron, which owed more than $67 billion after collapsing into bankruptcy protection, can seek creditors' support for a recovery plan that gives them most of the energy company's assets, a federal judge ruled yesterday. The judge, Arthur Gonzalez, at a hearing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, approved Enron's description of its strategy for exiting Chapter 11, which would give creditors stock in companies holding Enron's overseas assets and North American natural gas pipelines, more than $7 billion in cash and proceeds from lawsuits. Enron can now send the proposal to creditors for a vote. With sufficient creditor support, Enron, which is based in Houston, can seek court authorization to leave bankruptcy.
docs.abstract: Federal Judge Arthur Gonzalez rules Enron Corp, which owed more than $67 billion after collapsing into bankruptcy protection, can seek creditors' support for recovery plan that gives them ost of company's assets (S)

headline.main: ENRON RECOVERY PLAN ALLOWED TO PROCEED
